subject: Re: [junit] would like to contribute
msgSnippet: Indeed, we do not use automatic mocking frameworks for JUnit s self-tests. In many places, we test features by what you might consider integration-style,
messageBody:
Indeed, we do not use automatic mocking frameworks for JUnit's self-tests.
In many places, we test features by what you might consider
integration-style, constructing test classes that use the feature, and
asserting the desired outcomes. In some others, we use hand-rolled mocks.

Let me know if you have any questions about translating particular idioms.

David Saff

On Tue, Feb 12, 2013 at 2:46 PM, Noel Yap <noel.yap@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> I have created better support for filters (primarily
> CategoriesIncludeFilter and CategoriesExcludeFilter but any Filter can
> be plugged in, including an IgnoreFilter that uses the filter
> mechanism to support @Ignore). I would like to contribute this code to
> the JUnit project but it uses mocks for some of the testing. What
> mocking framework does the JUnit project use in its testing? If it
> currently doesn't use a mocking framework, should I rewrite the tests
> to be more end-to-end?
>
> Thanks,
> Noel
>
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
